description: From Middle English hucche (“storage chest”), variation of whucce, from Old English hwiċe, hwiċċe (“box, chest”). Spelling influenced by Old French huche (“chest”), from Medieval Latin hūtica, from a different Germanic root, from Frankish *hutta, from Proto-Germanic *hudjō, *hudjǭ (“box, hut, hutch”). Akin to Old English hȳdan (“to conceal; hide”). More at hide, hut.

entries.meaning: A box, chest, crate, case or cabinet.
A coop or cage for keeping small animals (rabbits, guinea pigs, dogs, etc).
A piece of furniture in which items may be displayed.
A piece of furniture (cabinet) to be placed on top of a desk.
A measure of two Winchester bushels.
(mining) The case of a flour bolt.
(mining) A car on low wheels, in which coal is drawn in the mine and hoisted out of the pit.
(mining) A jig or trough for ore dressing or washing ore.

verbs.description: hutch (third-person singular simple present hutches, present participle hutching, simple past and past participle hutched)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To hoard or lay up, in a chest.
(mining, transitive) To wash (ore) in a box or jig.
(ambiintransitive) To move with a jerk; to hitch.
examples: And the mind was very disinclined to hutch out of the crevice and face what must be done.  […]  He hauled himself out of the crevice and the air was warm so that he undressed to trousers and sweater.  […]   He hutched himself back against a rock with his legs sprawled apart.
